title: Financial Statement Analysis – Ultra Detailed Revision Edition
overview: Financial Statement Analysis (20% of Part 2) is about reading between the numbers. It requires mastery of comparative analysis techniques (horizontal, vertical, common-size), all five ratio categories (Liquidity, Leverage, Activity, Profitability, Market), the DuPont framework, profitability decomposition, and special issues including foreign currency translation, inflation effects, and earnings quality. The CMA exam tests interpretation and judgment — not just formula recall.
bulletNotes: **Horizontal Analysis**: Year-over-year % change. Base year = denominator. Identifies trends.
**Vertical Analysis (Common-Size)**: Each line as % of total (BS: Total Assets; IS: Net Sales). Enables cross-company comparison.
**Liquidity**: Current Ratio (CA/CL), Quick Ratio ((Cash+Mkt Sec+AR)/CL), Cash Ratio (Cash/CL). Higher = more liquid.
**Leverage**: Debt-to-Equity (Total Debt/Equity), Debt-to-Assets (Total Debt/Total Assets), TIE (EBIT/Interest).
**Activity**: Inventory Turnover (COGS/Avg Inv), AR Turnover (Credit Sales/Avg AR), AP Turnover (COGS/Avg AP). Days = 365/Turnover.
**CCC**: Days Inventory + DSO – DPO. Lower is better. Negative CCC = suppliers finance operations.
**Profitability**: Gross Margin, Operating Margin, Net Margin, EBITDA Margin, ROA, ROE.
**DuPont (3-factor)**: ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier.
**FX Translation**: Current Rate Method (independent sub) → OCI. Temporal Method (integrated sub) → Net Income.
**Earnings Quality**: High quality = recurring, cash-backed, conservative accounting. Watch for one-time gains.
shortNotes: Always use AVERAGE balance sheet figures when mixing with income statement data (ROA, Turnover ratios). DuPont is the #1 tested framework — know all three components and what drives each. For FX: Current Rate = OCI; Temporal = Net Income. Earnings quality questions require judgment about sustainability of reported earnings.

concepts.title: 1. Comparative Financial Statement Analysis
concepts.content:
Horizontal Analysis (Trend Analysis)

Compares financial data across multiple periods to identify trends.

  • Formula: (Current Year – Base Year) / Base Year × 100%
  • Base year is always the denominator.
  • Identifies growth rates for revenue, expenses, assets, and liabilities.
  • Example: Revenue grew from $500K to $600K → Change = $100K / $500K = 20% increase.

Vertical Analysis (Common-Size Statements)

Expresses each line item as a percentage of a base figure within the same period.

  • Income Statement: Each item as % of Net Sales/Revenue.
  • Balance Sheet: Each item as % of Total Assets.
  • Purpose: Enables comparison across companies of different sizes and across time periods.
  • Example: COGS = $300K, Sales = $500K → COGS % = 60%.

Trend Analysis

Uses an index to compare multiple years to a base year (base = 100).

  • If Year 3 revenue index = 125, revenue grew 25% from the base year.
  • Useful for identifying acceleration or deceleration in growth.

concepts.title: 2. Liquidity Ratios – Short-Term Solvency
concepts.content:
Measure the company's ability to meet short-term obligations as they come due.

RatioFormulaInterpretation
Current RatioCurrent Assets / Current Liabilities>2 = strong; <1 = concern. Includes inventory.
Quick Ratio (Acid-Test)(Cash + Mkt Sec + Net AR) / CLExcludes inventory and prepaids. More conservative.
Cash RatioCash + Mkt Securities / CLMost conservative. Immediate payment ability.
Net Working CapitalCurrent Assets – Current LiabilitiesAbsolute dollar measure of liquidity buffer.
Cash Flow RatioCFO / Current LiabilitiesUses actual cash generated, not accrual-based assets.

Key Insight: A high current ratio is not always good. It may indicate excess inventory (slow-moving) or uncollected receivables. Always compare the quick ratio to assess true liquidity.

concepts.title: 3. Leverage (Solvency) Ratios – Long-Term Risk
concepts.content:
Measure the extent to which a company uses debt financing and its ability to service that debt.

RatioFormulaInterpretation
Debt-to-EquityTotal Liabilities / Total EquityHigher = more leveraged = more risk.
Debt-to-AssetsTotal Debt / Total Assets% of assets financed by creditors.
Equity MultiplierTotal Assets / Total EquityUsed in DuPont. Higher = more leverage.
Times Interest Earned (TIE)EBIT / Interest ExpenseHow many times EBIT covers interest. <1 = danger.
Debt Service CoverageEBIT / (Interest + Principal/(1-t))Covers both interest and principal payments.

Financial Risk: Leverage amplifies returns when ROA > cost of debt, but amplifies losses when ROA < cost of debt. This is the double-edged sword of leverage.

concepts.title: 4. Activity (Efficiency) Ratios
concepts.content:
Measure how efficiently a company manages its assets to generate revenue.

RatioFormulaDays Equivalent
Inventory TurnoverCOGS / Average InventoryDays Inventory = 365 / Inv Turnover
AR TurnoverNet Credit Sales / Average ARDSO = 365 / AR Turnover
AP TurnoverCOGS / Average APDPO = 365 / AP Turnover
Asset TurnoverNet Sales / Average Total AssetsRevenue generated per $ of assets
Fixed Asset TurnoverNet Sales / Average Net Fixed AssetsEfficiency of long-term asset use

Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC)

CCC = Days Inventory Held + Days Sales Outstanding – Days Payables Outstanding

  • Measures how long cash is tied up in operations.
  • Lower CCC = Better (cash recycled faster).
  • Negative CCC (e.g., Amazon, Walmart) = suppliers finance operations.

Operating Cycle: Days Inventory + DSO (excludes payables).

concepts.title: 5. Profitability Ratios
concepts.content:
Measure the company's ability to generate profit relative to sales, assets, and equity.

RatioFormulaWhat It Measures
Gross Profit MarginGross Profit / Net SalesPricing power and production efficiency
Operating Profit MarginEBIT / Net SalesCore operating profitability
Net Profit MarginNet Income / Net SalesBottom-line profitability after all costs
EBITDA MarginEBITDA / Net SalesCash-generating ability before financing/taxes
ROANet Income / Average Total AssetsReturn generated on all assets
ROENet Income / Average EquityReturn to common shareholders
ROCEEBIT / (Total Assets – CL)Return on long-term capital employed

Basic EPS: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Avg Common Shares

Diluted EPS: Includes effect of convertible securities and options. Always ≤ Basic EPS.

concepts.title: 6. Market (Valuation) Ratios
concepts.content:
Relate market price to financial performance metrics.

RatioFormulaInterpretation
Price/Earnings (P/E)Market Price / EPSHow much investors pay per $1 of earnings. Higher = growth expectations.
Earnings YieldEPS / Market PriceInverse of P/E. Return on market price.
Dividend YieldDividends per Share / Market PriceIncome return on investment.
Dividend Payout RatioDividends per Share / EPS% of earnings paid as dividends.
Market-to-Book RatioMarket Price / Book Value per Share>1 = market values firm above accounting value.
Book Value per Share(Total Equity – Preferred Equity) / Common SharesAccounting value per share.

concepts.title: 7. DuPont Analysis – Decomposing ROE
concepts.content:
3-Factor DuPont Model

ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

ROE = (NI/Sales) × (Sales/Assets) × (Assets/Equity)

ComponentMeasuresDriven By
Net Profit MarginProfitability / EfficiencyPricing, cost control, tax management
Asset TurnoverProductivity / EfficiencyRevenue generation from assets
Equity MultiplierFinancial Leverage / RiskDebt vs equity financing mix

5-Factor DuPont Model

ROE = Tax Burden × Interest Burden × EBIT Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

  • Tax Burden: NI / EBT (% of pre-tax income kept after taxes).
  • Interest Burden: EBT / EBIT (impact of interest expense).

Analytical Use

If ROE increases, DuPont identifies why:

  • Higher margin → better pricing or cost control.
  • Higher turnover → more efficient asset use.
  • Higher leverage → more debt (increases risk).

Exam Trap: ROE can increase due to higher leverage even when the business is deteriorating (lower margins, lower turnover).

concepts.title: 8. Profitability Analysis – Revenue, Cost & Variation
concepts.content:
Revenue Analysis

  • Assess source (product lines, geographies), stability (recurring vs one-time), and trend (growing, declining).
  • Relationship between revenue and receivables: If AR grows faster than revenue → collection issues.
  • Relationship between revenue and inventory: If inventory grows faster than revenue → demand slowdown.

Cost of Sales Analysis

  • Gross margin trend: Declining margin may indicate rising input costs, pricing pressure, or product mix shift.
  • Compare gross margin to industry benchmarks.

Expense Analysis

  • Operating leverage: High fixed costs → profits more sensitive to revenue changes.
  • SG&A as % of sales: Rising % may indicate inefficiency.

Variation Analysis

  • Identify unusual fluctuations in line items period-over-period.
  • Investigate items that deviate significantly from trend.

concepts.title: 9. Special Issues – Foreign Currency Translation
concepts.content:
When a parent consolidates a foreign subsidiary, the subsidiary's financials must be translated into the parent's reporting currency.

FeatureCurrent Rate MethodTemporal Method
When UsedSubsidiary is independent (functional currency = local currency)Subsidiary is integrated (functional currency = parent's currency)
Assets & LiabilitiesAll at current (spot) rateMonetary at current rate; Non-monetary at historical rate
Revenue & ExpensesAt average rate for the periodMost at average rate; COGS/Depreciation at historical rate
EquityAt historical rateAt historical rate
Gains/LossesTranslation adjustment → OCIRemeasurement gain/loss → Net Income

Memory Aid: Current Rate = OCI (Cushioned). Temporal = Net Income (Hits earnings directly).

Monetary vs Non-Monetary Assets:

  • Monetary: Cash, AR, AP, Notes Payable (fixed dollar amounts).
  • Non-monetary: Inventory, PPE, Prepaid expenses (not fixed dollar amounts).

concepts.title: 10. Special Issues – Inflation, Accounting Changes & Earnings Quality
concepts.content:
Effects of Changing Prices / Inflation

  • Inflation distorts historical cost financial statements.
  • FIFO inventory and depreciation on old assets are understated in real terms.
  • Real profitability may be lower than reported under historical cost.
  • Analysts adjust for inflation using price-level adjusted statements.

Impact of Changes in Accounting Treatment

  • Changes in accounting policies (e.g., depreciation method, inventory method) affect comparability.
  • Analysts must restate prior periods to ensure apples-to-apples comparison.
  • Watch for: changes in revenue recognition timing, capitalization vs expensing decisions.

Earnings Quality

High-quality earnings are:

  • Recurring: From core operations, not one-time gains.
  • Cash-backed: Supported by operating cash flow (CFO ≈ Net Income).
  • Conservative: Not inflated by aggressive accounting choices.
  • Consistent: Same accounting policies applied period to period.

Red Flags for Low Earnings Quality:

  • Net Income >> CFO (accruals not converting to cash).
  • Frequent changes in accounting estimates.
  • Large non-recurring gains boosting income.
  • Channel stuffing (inflating revenue near period end).
  • Capitalizing expenses that should be expensed.

Accounting vs Economic Value

  • Book value (accounting) uses historical cost.
  • Economic value reflects future cash flows discounted at cost of capital.
  • Market value (stock price) reflects investor expectations of future economic value.

formulas.name: Quick Ratio
formulas.formula: (Cash + Marketable Securities + Net AR) / Current Liabilities

formulas.name: AR Turnover
formulas.formula: Net Credit Sales / Average Accounts Receivable

formulas.name: DuPont ROE (3-factor)
formulas.formula: Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

formulas.name: Basic EPS
formulas.formula: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares

formulas.name: Dividend Yield
formulas.formula: Dividends per Share / Market Price per Share

formulas.name: Book Value per Share
formulas.formula: (Total Equity – Preferred Equity) / Common Shares Outstanding

mistakes: Using **end-of-year** balance sheet figures instead of **averages** for ratios that mix income statement and balance sheet data (ROA, Turnover ratios).
Forgetting to subtract **Preferred Dividends** from Net Income when calculating Basic EPS or ROE for common shareholders.
Confusing **Current Rate Method** (OCI) with **Temporal Method** (Net Income) for FX translation.
Thinking a **lower DSO** is bad. Lower DSO means collecting cash faster — it is good.
Assuming **higher ROE** always means better performance. ROE can rise due to increased leverage even when operations deteriorate.
Using **Sales** instead of **COGS** as the numerator for Inventory Turnover (COGS is correct).
Confusing **Diluted EPS** with Basic EPS. Diluted EPS is always ≤ Basic EPS.
Thinking **earnings quality** is only about fraud. It also includes aggressive-but-legal accounting choices.

quiz.question: Which ratio measures the ability of a firm to meet its short-term obligations with its most liquid assets?
quiz.explanation: The Quick Ratio excludes inventory and prepaids, using only Cash, Marketable Securities, and AR — the most liquid assets.

quiz.question: If a company's Asset Turnover increases while Profit Margin and Financial Leverage remain constant, ROE will:
quiz.explanation: DuPont: ROE = Margin × Turnover × Leverage. An increase in any component increases ROE.

quiz.question: Under the Current Rate Method of foreign currency translation, translation gains/losses are reported in:
quiz.explanation: Current Rate Method (independent subsidiary) → translation adjustment goes to OCI (equity).

quiz.question: The Cash Conversion Cycle equals:
quiz.explanation: CCC = Days Inventory Held + Days Sales Outstanding – Days Payables Outstanding.

quiz.question: In vertical analysis of an income statement, each item is expressed as a percentage of:
quiz.explanation: In vertical analysis of the income statement, Net Sales is the base (100%) and all items are expressed as a % of it.

essay.question: Analyst A claims that increasing financial leverage is always beneficial because it boosts ROE. 1) Explain how leverage impacts ROE using the DuPont framework. 2) Discuss the risks associated with this strategy. 3) Describe two red flags that would indicate low earnings quality.
essay.modelAnswer:
1. Leverage and ROE (DuPont):
ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier. Increasing debt raises the Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity). If ROA > after-tax cost of debt, leverage magnifies returns to shareholders.

2. Associated Risk:
Interest payments are fixed obligations. In a downturn, if ROA falls below the cost of debt, leverage works in reverse — drastically reducing ROE and potentially leading to insolvency. Higher leverage also increases the TIE risk (EBIT may not cover interest).

3. Earnings Quality Red Flags:
(a) Net Income significantly exceeds CFO — earnings are not converting to cash, suggesting aggressive accruals.
(b) Frequent changes in accounting estimates or policies — may indicate management is manipulating reported results.

summary: Financial Statement Analysis (20%) requires mastery of comparative techniques (horizontal, vertical, trend), all five ratio categories, the DuPont framework, profitability decomposition, and special issues (FX translation, inflation, earnings quality). Success means interpreting what ratios reveal about business health — not just calculating them.

test.question: Horizontal analysis compares financial data:
options: Across companies of the same size
As a percentage of total assets
As a percentage of net sales
test.explanation: Horizontal analysis tracks changes in financial data over multiple periods to identify trends.

test.question: In horizontal analysis, the base year figure is used as the:
test.explanation: % Change = (Current – Base) / Base. The base year is always the denominator.

test.question: Vertical analysis of the income statement expresses each item as a % of:
test.explanation: In income statement vertical analysis, Net Sales = 100% base.

test.question: Vertical analysis of the balance sheet expresses each item as a % of:
test.explanation: In balance sheet vertical analysis, Total Assets = 100% base.

test.question: Common-size financial statements are most useful for:
test.explanation: Common-size statements remove size differences, enabling meaningful cross-company comparison.

test.question: If revenue was $400K in Year 1 and $500K in Year 2, the horizontal analysis % change is:
Trend analysis uses a base year index of:
test.explanation: In trend analysis, the base year = 100. Subsequent years are expressed as an index relative to 100.

test.question: The Current Ratio formula is:
test.explanation: Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities.

test.question: The Quick Ratio excludes which current asset?
test.explanation: The Quick Ratio excludes inventory and prepaid expenses — the least liquid current assets.

test.question: The most conservative liquidity ratio is:
test.explanation: Cash Ratio = (Cash + Mkt Securities) / CL. Uses only the most liquid assets.

test.question: Net Working Capital equals:
test.explanation: NWC = Current Assets – Current Liabilities. A positive NWC indicates liquidity buffer.

test.question: A Current Ratio of 0.8 indicates:
test.explanation: CR < 1 means CL > CA — the company may struggle to meet short-term obligations.

test.question: A high Current Ratio may indicate:
options: Possible excess inventory or slow collections
test.explanation: High CR could mean obsolete inventory or uncollected AR — not necessarily good liquidity.

test.question: Times Interest Earned (TIE) is calculated as:
test.explanation: TIE = EBIT / Interest Expense. Measures how many times operating income covers interest.

test.question: A TIE ratio below 1.0 indicates:
options: The company cannot cover interest from operations
test.explanation: TIE < 1 means EBIT < Interest Expense — the company is burning cash to pay lenders.

test.question: Debt-to-Equity ratio equals:
test.explanation: D/E = Total Liabilities / Total Equity. Measures financial leverage.

test.question: The Equity Multiplier equals:
test.explanation: Equity Multiplier = Total Assets / Total Equity. Used in DuPont analysis.

test.question: Inventory Turnover is calculated using:
test.explanation: Inventory Turnover = COGS / Average Inventory. COGS (not Sales) is the correct numerator.

test.question: Days Inventory Outstanding (DIO) equals:
test.explanation: DIO = 365 / Inventory Turnover. Measures average days to sell inventory.

test.question: AR Turnover is calculated as:
test.explanation: AR Turnover = Net Credit Sales / Average AR. Measures collection efficiency.

test.question: Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) measures:
test.explanation: DSO = 365 / AR Turnover. Lower DSO = faster collection = better.

test.question: Days Payables Outstanding (DPO) measures:
test.explanation: DPO = 365 / AP Turnover. Higher DPO = company takes longer to pay suppliers (favorable for cash flow).

test.question: The Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC) equals:
test.explanation: CCC = Days Inventory + Days Sales Outstanding – Days Payables Outstanding.

test.question: A negative Cash Conversion Cycle means:
test.explanation: Negative CCC (e.g., Amazon) means the company collects cash before paying suppliers — suppliers finance operations.

test.question: Asset Turnover measures:
options: Revenue generated per dollar of assets
test.explanation: Asset Turnover = Net Sales / Average Total Assets. Measures asset productivity.

test.question: Gross Profit Margin equals:
test.explanation: Gross Profit Margin = Gross Profit / Net Sales. Measures pricing power and production efficiency.

test.question: Operating Profit Margin uses which income figure?
test.explanation: Operating Profit Margin = EBIT / Net Sales. Excludes interest and taxes.

test.question: EBITDA Margin is useful because it:
options: Approximates cash-generating ability before financing and taxes
test.explanation: EBITDA adds back D&A to operating income, approximating operating cash flow before financing/taxes.

test.question: ROA equals:
test.explanation: ROA = Net Income / Average Total Assets. Measures return on all assets regardless of financing.

test.question: ROE equals:
test.explanation: ROE = Net Income / Average Shareholders' Equity. The primary return metric for common shareholders.

test.question: The 3-factor DuPont formula for ROE is:
test.explanation: ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity).

test.question: In DuPont analysis, if ROE rises only because the Equity Multiplier increased, this indicates:
test.explanation: A rising Equity Multiplier means more debt relative to equity — higher financial risk, not better operations.

test.question: The 5-factor DuPont model adds which two components?
options: Asset turnover and fixed asset turnover
test.explanation: The 5-factor model splits the net profit margin into: Tax Burden (NI/EBT) × Interest Burden (EBT/EBIT) × EBIT Margin.

test.question: Basic EPS equals:
options: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Avg Common Shares
test.explanation: Basic EPS = (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares Outstanding.

test.question: Diluted EPS is always:
options: Equal to or less than Basic EPS
test.explanation: Diluted EPS includes the effect of convertible securities and options, which increase shares — reducing EPS.

test.question: The P/E ratio equals:
test.explanation: P/E = Market Price per Share / EPS. Shows how much investors pay per $1 of earnings.

test.question: A high P/E ratio typically indicates:
test.explanation: High P/E = investors expect high future growth OR the stock may be overvalued.

test.question: Dividend Yield equals:
test.explanation: Dividend Yield = Dividends per Share / Market Price. Measures income return on investment.

test.question: Dividend Payout Ratio equals:
test.explanation: Payout Ratio = Dividends per Share / EPS. Shows what % of earnings is paid as dividends.

test.question: Market-to-Book ratio greater than 1 indicates:
options: Market values the firm below accounting value
Market values the firm above accounting value
test.explanation: M/B > 1 means investors believe the firm is worth more than its accounting (book) value.

test.question: Book Value per Share equals:
test.explanation: Book Value per Share = (Total Equity – Preferred Equity) / Common Shares Outstanding.

test.question: The Operating Cycle equals:
test.explanation: Operating Cycle = Days Inventory + DSO. It excludes payables (unlike CCC).

test.question: Which activity ratio uses COGS in the numerator?
test.explanation: Inventory Turnover = COGS / Average Inventory. COGS is correct (not Sales).

test.question: If Inventory Turnover increases, Days Inventory Outstanding will:
test.explanation: DIO = 365 / Inventory Turnover. Higher turnover → fewer days to sell inventory.

test.question: A company with DSO of 45 days and DPO of 60 days has a favorable position because:
options: It collects faster than it pays
It pays faster than it collects
test.explanation: Collecting in 45 days but paying in 60 days means suppliers are financing operations — favorable cash position.

test.question: Under the Temporal Method, non-monetary assets are translated at:
test.explanation: Temporal Method: Non-monetary assets (inventory, PPE) use historical exchange rates.

test.question: Under the Current Rate Method, all assets and liabilities are translated at:
test.explanation: Current Rate Method translates all assets and liabilities at the current (closing) spot rate.

test.question: Remeasurement gains/losses under the Temporal Method are reported in:
test.explanation: Temporal Method (integrated subsidiary) → remeasurement gains/losses go directly to Net Income.

test.question: Translation adjustments under the Current Rate Method are reported in:
test.explanation: Current Rate Method → translation adjustment accumulates in OCI as Cumulative Translation Adjustment (CTA).

test.question: Which assets are classified as 'monetary' for Temporal Method purposes?
test.explanation: Monetary assets/liabilities have fixed dollar amounts: Cash, AR, AP, Notes Payable.

test.question: Revenue and expenses under the Current Rate Method are translated at:
test.explanation: Under the Current Rate Method, income statement items are translated at the average rate for the period.

test.question: High earnings quality is characterized by:
options: Net income much higher than CFO
test.explanation: High quality earnings are recurring, supported by operating cash flow, and based on conservative accounting.

test.question: A red flag for low earnings quality is:
test.explanation: When NI >> CFO, earnings are not converting to cash — suggesting aggressive accruals or manipulation.

test.question: Channel stuffing is an example of:
test.explanation: Channel stuffing involves pushing excess inventory to distributors to inflate reported revenue — low quality.

test.question: Capitalizing expenses that should be expensed results in:
test.explanation: Capitalizing costs defers expense recognition, inflating current period income — aggressive accounting.

test.question: Inflation distorts historical cost financial statements by:
options: Understating depreciation and inventory costs in real terms
test.explanation: Inflation means old assets and FIFO inventory are understated in real (current) dollar terms.

test.question: When comparing two companies, a lower net profit margin may still be acceptable if:
options: The company has much higher asset turnover (e.g., retail)
test.explanation: High-volume, low-margin businesses (retail) compensate with high asset turnover — DuPont shows this.

test.question: Which ratio best measures a company's ability to generate cash to service debt?
test.explanation: Cash Flow Ratio = CFO / Current Liabilities. Uses actual cash generated, not accrual-based figures.

test.question: If AR grows faster than revenue, this may indicate:
options: Collection problems or aggressive revenue recognition
test.explanation: AR growing faster than revenue suggests customers are not paying promptly or revenue is being recognized too early.

test.question: If inventory grows faster than revenue, this may indicate:
test.explanation: Inventory growing faster than revenue suggests products are not selling — potential obsolescence risk.

test.question: The Debt-to-Assets ratio measures:
options: What % of assets are financed by creditors
test.explanation: Debt-to-Assets = Total Debt / Total Assets. Shows the proportion of assets financed by debt.

test.question: A company with high operating leverage has:
options: High fixed costs relative to total costs
test.explanation: High operating leverage = high fixed costs. Profits are more sensitive to revenue changes.

test.question: EBITDA stands for:
options: Earnings Before Taxes and Depreciation Adjustments
Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization
Estimated Basis of Total Debt Allocation
Earnings Before Income Tax and Dividends Accrued
test.explanation: EBITDA = Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization.

test.question: Which ratio is most useful for comparing companies with different capital structures?
test.explanation: EBITDA Margin excludes interest (financing) and D&A (accounting choices), enabling better cross-company comparison.

test.question: Fixed Asset Turnover measures:
options: Revenue generated per dollar of net fixed assets
Fixed assets as % of total assets
test.explanation: Fixed Asset Turnover = Net Sales / Average Net Fixed Assets. Measures efficiency of long-term asset use.

test.question: When calculating ROA, the denominator should be:
test.explanation: ROA uses Average Total Assets because net income is earned over the period, not at a point in time.

test.question: Earnings Yield equals:
test.explanation: Earnings Yield = EPS / Market Price. It is the inverse of the P/E ratio.

test.question: A company has Net Income = $200K, Preferred Dividends = $20K, Common Shares = 90K. Basic EPS is:
Which of the following would DECREASE the Current Ratio?
options: Paying a current liability with cash
test.explanation: Buying inventory on credit increases both CA (inventory) and CL (AP) equally — but if CR > 1, this decreases it.

test.question: Which of the following would INCREASE the Quick Ratio?
test.explanation: Collecting AR converts a quick asset (AR) to cash — no change in numerator, but if it reduces CL, QR rises. Actually collecting AR doesn't change the QR numerator total (AR → Cash, both are quick assets). Paying off current liabilities with quick assets increases QR.

test.question: A company's ROE is 15%, ROA is 10%. The Equity Multiplier is approximately:
test.explanation: ROE = ROA × Equity Multiplier → 15% = 10% × EM → EM = 1.5.

test.question: If a company's Net Profit Margin is 5%, Asset Turnover is 2.0, and Equity Multiplier is 3.0, ROE is:
Declining gross margin over time most likely indicates:
options: Rising input costs or pricing pressure
test.explanation: Declining gross margin = COGS rising faster than revenue → input cost increases or competitive pricing pressure.

test.question: SG&A as a % of sales increasing over time suggests:
test.explanation: Rising SG&A % means overhead is growing faster than revenue — potential inefficiency.

test.question: The functional currency of a foreign subsidiary is determined by:
options: The currency of the primary economic environment where the subsidiary operates
The currency of the country where the parent is headquartered
The currency used for tax reporting
test.explanation: The functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment where the subsidiary operates.

test.question: Under the Temporal Method, COGS is translated at:
options: Historical rate (rate when inventory was purchased)
test.explanation: Temporal Method: COGS is translated at the historical rate (when the inventory was acquired).

test.question: A company's Inventory Turnover is 6. Its Days Inventory Outstanding is:
A company's DSO is 30 days and DPO is 45 days. Its operating cycle (DIO = 40 days) CCC is:
test.explanation: CCC = DIO + DSO – DPO = 40 + 30 – 45 = 25 days.

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of high earnings quality?
test.explanation: Large non-recurring gains are a sign of LOW earnings quality — they are not sustainable.

test.question: Book value per share would DECREASE if:
options: The company issues new shares at a premium
The company repurchases shares above book value
test.explanation: Repurchasing shares above book value reduces total equity more than it reduces share count, lowering BVPS.

test.question: Which ratio is most relevant for a creditor evaluating long-term solvency?
test.explanation: TIE measures how well EBIT covers interest — directly relevant to long-term debt service ability.

test.question: A company with a high dividend payout ratio is likely:
options: A mature company returning cash to shareholders
test.explanation: Mature companies with stable earnings tend to pay high dividends; growth companies retain earnings.

test.question: Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) uses which income figure?
test.explanation: ROCE = EBIT / Capital Employed. Uses EBIT to measure return before financing costs.

test.question: Capital Employed in ROCE equals:
test.explanation: Capital Employed = Total Assets – Current Liabilities (= Long-term Debt + Equity).

test.question: Frequent changes in accounting estimates are a sign of:
test.explanation: Frequent changes in estimates (useful life, bad debt %, warranty %) can be used to manage reported earnings.

test.question: Which method of foreign currency translation is used when the subsidiary's functional currency equals the parent's reporting currency?
test.explanation: Temporal Method (Remeasurement) is used when the subsidiary's functional currency = parent's reporting currency.

test.question: Under the Current Rate Method, equity accounts are translated at:
test.explanation: Equity accounts (common stock, APIC) are translated at historical rates under the Current Rate Method.

test.question: A company's P/E ratio is 20 and EPS is $3. The market price per share is:
test.explanation: Market Price = P/E × EPS = 20 × $3 = $60.

test.question: Which of the following would improve a company's Asset Turnover?
options: Increasing assets while holding sales constant
Increasing sales while holding assets constant
test.explanation: Asset Turnover = Sales / Assets. Increasing sales with the same asset base improves turnover.

test.question: The relationship between revenue and receivables is important because:
options: It reveals collection efficiency and potential revenue quality issues
test.explanation: If AR grows faster than revenue, it may signal collection problems or premature revenue recognition.

test.question: Which of the following is a market (valuation) ratio?
test.explanation: P/E is a market ratio — it relates market price to earnings per share.

test.question: A company has Total Assets = $1M, Total Equity = $400K. The Equity Multiplier is:
test.explanation: Equity Multiplier = Total Assets / Total Equity = $1M / $400K = 2.5.

test.question: Which of the following best describes 'economic value' vs 'book value'?
options: Economic value reflects future cash flows; book value uses historical cost
Economic value is based on GAAP
test.explanation: Economic value = PV of future cash flows. Book value = historical cost accounting. They differ significantly.

test.question: A company's gross margin declined from 40% to 35%. This most likely indicates:
test.explanation: Declining gross margin = COGS growing faster than revenue (input costs up or selling prices down).

test.question: Which of the following is the BEST indicator of a company's ability to pay dividends?
test.explanation: Dividends are paid in cash. CFO best indicates whether the company generates enough cash to sustain dividends.

test.question: Trend analysis with a base year index of 100 shows Year 3 revenue index of 140. This means:
options: Revenue grew 40% from the base year
test.explanation: Index 140 means revenue is 140% of base year — a 40% increase from the base year.

test.question: Which of the following would NOT be eliminated when computing the Quick Ratio?
test.explanation: AR is included in the Quick Ratio numerator. Inventory, prepaids, and supplies are excluded.

test.question: A company's Net Profit Margin is 8%, Asset Turnover is 1.5. Its ROA is:
test.explanation: ROA = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover = 8% × 1.5 = 12%.

test.question: Which of the following best describes 'financial leverage' in the DuPont framework?
test.explanation: The Equity Multiplier (Assets/Equity) represents financial leverage in the 3-factor DuPont model.

test.question: A company reports Net Income of $500K and CFO of $150K. This pattern most likely indicates:
test.explanation: NI >> CFO suggests earnings are not converting to cash — a red flag for earnings quality.
